name: Emilia AOSE
comment info:
I notice first in these graphs that each color represents something different, whether it be a record, a current finding, or a prediction. It is obvious that southern states have drastically higher temperatures than northern cities this time of year. In a lot of these cities, people are experiencing drastic temperature fluctuations.  Atlanta, Boston, Minneapolis, and New York are all cities that experienced 30-degree differences in just five days. In other cities, temperatures are not near the expected temperatures, but rather near the record highs and lows. Cities like Dallas, Fort Myers, Orlando, and Tampa all reached temperatures above the normal high. More rare were cities dipping below their normal lows, but it did happen briefly in Denver and Minneapolis.
What I am most curious about in this graph is the cause for such drastic fluctuations in weather and why many cities are experiencing extreme highs and lows in temperature. This is likely in part due to global warming. I am also curious if the cities whose forecasts were rather drastic reached their predicted temperatures. 
This relates to me and my community because we have been experiencing drastic weather ourselves. Here, the weather was nearing zero degrees last week, but just days later it neared 50 degrees. 
A catchphrase for this graph is "Wacky Weather Sweeps the Nation".

name: Uliana AOSE
comment info:
I notice that the graph shows the high and low temperatures Dec. 6-10 and the forecasted high and low temperatures for Dec. 11-15. The light gray bars of the graph show the average temperature in past years during this time. Particularly cities on the east coast saw higher than the average temperatures. Cities in the northeast, like Boston that are generally colder, recorded temperatures over 40 degrees for Dec. 6-10. While cities on the west coast experienced lower than the average temperature recorded. 

I wonder if the predicted forecasts were accurate and if they followed similar trends to Dec. 6-10. I also wonder the connections to climate change and global warming. 

This affects my community because I live in New Jersey, which is on the East Coast. New Jersey generally has colder winters, but the weather has been generally warmer, in the 50s and 60s. The lack of snow this season makes me concerned about the affects of global warming on my community.

Headline: 
Global Warming: The Cold Places are becoming Warmer, and the Warm places are becoming Colder.

name: Charlotte AOSE
comment info:
I noticed that the graph shows that each area experienced at least mild fluctuation of the high and low forecasts. Additionally, forecasts for each individual city always correspond at least slightly with the actual temperatures for the previous week. For example, in Denver, the ranges for actual highs and lows experienced a dip Thursday, and the same pattern is seen in the forecast for the next Thursday. Only a few cities greatly stray from this pattern, including Minneapolis, New York, and Portland, Oregon. 

I wonder if weather forecasts are often based on the previous week(s), and exactly what other factors are taken into account. I also wonder how accurate these forecasts ultimately were and if the accuracy of the results affects how forecasts are made in the future.

This relates to me and my community because we are constantly checking weather forecasts in order to decide what to wear, where to go, and what to bring with us.

Headline: Forecasts - How Accurate Are They Really?

name: Colleen AOSE
comment info:
I notice in this graph that the temperatures of some of the areas in the north that would usually experience cold weather at this time, have higher temperatures than normal. Boston had temperatures over 40 degrees for four consecutive days. Additionally, Denver had temperatures reaching 60 degrees and some days forecasted to go over 60. Where areas in the north the temperature is increasing, it is the opposite for places in the south. Both Houston and Phoenix in the southern states of Texas and Arizona dropped to low temperatures reaching 40 and under, which is unlike usual weather during this time. I also notice that while in some areas, the temperatures remain consistent over the days from December 6 to December 10, some areas have varying  drops in temperature. In Boston, it goes from reaching the 50s, to dropping down to almost 20 degrees in the forecast. 
I wonder why some places have greater temperatures drops and rises than others that are more consistent. 
This relates to me and my community because it is noticeable the unnatural temperatures that New Jersey is experiencing in the months of winter that should be colder. The weather has been reaching near the 60s, which is irregular around this time. Last year it was snowing around the same time that the temperatures are rising now. This demonstrates how much global warming is effecting the world. 
Catchy Headline "Highs and Lows: How Global Warming is Affecting the Globe"

This graph impacts me and my community by showing the local, real-time impacts of climate change on our east coast environment as well as throughout the country. Due to an increased amount of human activity, pollution and greenhouse gases are becoming trapped in our atmosphere, heating up our planet.
